H0.text: Linear movement due west is the characteristic of the North Atlantic gyre that the scientist needs to know to track contaminant movement after it exits the Gulf Stream, a warm water current in the North Atlantic Ocean that is part of the gyre and is influenced by the Coriolis effect.

H1.text: Linear movement due south is the characteristic of the North Atlantic gyre that a scientist must know to track a contaminant after it exits the Gulf Stream, a warm water current in the North Atlantic Ocean that is part of the gyre influenced by the Coriolis effect.

H2.text: Clockwise movement is the characteristic of the North Atlantic gyre that a scientist needs to know to track contaminant movement after it exits the Gulf Stream, a warm water current in the North Atlantic Ocean that is part of the North Atlantic gyre and is influenced by the Coriolis effect.

H3.text: Counterclockwise movement is the characteristic of the North Atlantic gyre that the scientist needs to know to track contaminant movement after it exits the Gulf Stream, a warm water current in the North Atlantic Ocean that is part of the gyre and is influenced by the Coriolis effect.

A6.text: The North Atlantic Gyre is anticyclonic, rotating clockwise in the northern hemisphere due to the Coriolis force.

A7.text: All subtropical gyres are anticyclonic, meaning that in the northern hemisphere they rotate clockwise, while the gyres in the southern hemisphere rotate counterclockwise.
